Fitting for trending_model objects

Source: R/fit.r
fit.Rd

fit() fits a model using the given data to obtain an object of type trending_model_fit or trending_model_fit_list.

fit(x, data, ...)

# S3 method for trending_model
fit(x, data, ...)

# S3 method for list
fit(x, data, ...)

Arguments

x

The output of functions lm_model, glm_model, glm_nb_model, or brms_model or a list of these objects.
data

A data.frame to be used to train the model.
...

Additional arguments passed to underlying models.

Examples

x = rnorm(100, mean = 0)
y = rpois(n = 100, lambda = exp(1.5 + 0.5*x))
dat <- data.frame(x = x, y = y)

poisson_model <- glm_model(y ~ x , family = "poisson")
negbin_model <- glm_nb_model(y ~ x)

fit(poisson_model, dat)

#> $fitted_model
#> 
#> Call:  glm(formula = y ~ x, family = "poisson", data = data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)            x  
#>      1.5230       0.4625  
#> 
#> Degrees of Freedom: 99 Total (i.e. Null);  98 Residual
#> Null Deviance:	    233.5 
#> Residual Deviance: 114.8 	AIC: 446
#> 
#> $predict
#> function (newdata, alpha = 0.05, add_pi = TRUE, uncertain = TRUE) 
#> {
#>     if (missing(newdata)) {
#>         newdata <- model$model
#>     }
#>     result <- add_confidence_interval(model, newdata, alpha)
#>     if (add_pi) {
#>         result <- add_prediction_interval(model, result, alpha, 
#>             uncertain)
#>     }
#>     result
#> }
#> <bytecode: 0x7fecedd693c8>
#> <environment: 0x7fecedd6c3f8>
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "trending_model_fit" "list"              
fit(list(poisson_model, negbin_model), dat)

#> $fitted_trending_model
#> $fitted_trending_model[[1]]

#> 
#> Call:  glm(formula = y ~ x, family = "poisson", data = data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
